TEXT.English: When founding the Council, Natane approached The Eagle Tribe first. Natane and the Eagle Tribe leader at the time, Shimasani, believed that the tribes were becoming more and more radicalized as generations went on, as they essentially lived in an echo chamber. Shimasani, as a skilled negotiator, was able to bring the other tribal leaders into the Council one by one. Afterwards, she created programs where members of each tribe were made to intermingle with one another. Although these exchanges did not always go well, the process became easier over time.

TEXT.English: With the assistance of the Eagle Tribe, all of your cities will have +1 [ICON_HAPPY], your units will require 10% less experience to level up, and you'll receive +25% [ICON_FOOD] and [ICON_PRODUCTION] from trade routes. Further, you'll receive +2 relations with all other leaders.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Earning the favor of the Eagle Tribe is relatively easy if you're a peaceful player. They prefer to be at peace, and their preferred civic is [LINK=CIVIC_FOREIGN_TRADE]Foreign Trade[\LINK]. They also enjoy when you make deals with other players and when you construct buildings that provide happiness. If you're a peaceful player who likes to interact without other leaders, you will have no problems earning the favor of the Eagle Tribe.

TEXT.English: The Coyote Tribe, much to Natane's surprise, was the third tribe to join the Council. The Coyote Tribe is known as a clan of free-spirited folk, and Natane did not believe they would want to be held down by any regulations. Soyala of the Coyote Tribe saw the joining of the Council as an opportunity to make a lasting impact on the Chislev - to help them lighten up a little bit. Motsqueh was certainly a tough case to crack, but she eventually got through to him. Alosaka, when he would later join, was another story. The Coyote Tribe would often end up seeing eye-to-eye with the Serpent Tribe, who also prefered to live more on the wild side.

TEXT.English: With the assistance of the Coyote Tribe, you will receive +1 [ICON_CULTURE] per turn in each of your cities, a 50% increase of your Settler and Worker production, and your Settlers and Workers will start with [LINK=PROMOTION_MOBILITY1]Mobility I[\LINK]. You also receive unique [LINK=PROMOTION_DANCE_OF_THE_COYOTE]Dance of the Coyote[\LINK] promotion for your recon units, which provides 5 [ICON_CULTURE] per kill, +1 attack strength, and a +10% chance to withdrawal; however, it is removed after combat.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Members of the Coyote Tribe love music and exploring. You can keep them happy by using the [LINK=CIVIC_LIBERTY]Liberty[\LINK] civic, by founding cities, growing cities both in population and culture, and by exploring lairs and huts. They also enjoy pillaging, as the Coyote Tribe prefers war in a more hit-and-run style. As long as you keep expanding and growing, you should be able to earn the favor of the Coyote Tribe.

They also enjoy pillaging, as the Coyote Tribe prefers war in a more hit-and-run style. As long as you keep expanding and growing, you should be able to earn the favor of the Coyote Tribe.

TEXT.English: The Bear Tribe was the second tribe to join the Council. Their desire was relatively simple: as a builder tribe, they wanted more resources; and in return, they would supply their hardy warriors for the protection of the nation. Motsqueh, the leader of the Bear Tribe at the time of the Council's founding, often ended up being the tie breaker vote once all five tribes had been brought into the fold. Typically, the Eagle Tribe and the Tortoise Tribe tended to vote together, as they both preferred peace above all else. Meanwhile, the Serpent Tribe and Coyote Tribe tended to prefer more aggressive approaches, and even though their means to that end often differed, they did at least share a common goal. Although Motsqueh did tend to vote with Shimasani and Alosaka more often, it was not uncommon for Osyka and Soyala to convince him otherwise.

TEXT.English: Earning the Bear Tribe's favor will net you +3 [ICON_HEALTHY], +25% [ICON_PRODUCTION] towards wonders, and +1 [ICON_PRODUCTION] on plots that produce 3 [ICON_PRODUCTION].[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Favor with Motsqueh can be earned by constructing any buildings. Wonders will provide more favor than normal buildings. Buildings that provide health will also provide more favor than normal. Since these effects stack, a wonder that produces health provides a huge favor bonus with the Bear Tribe. The Bear Tribe's favored civic is [LINK=CIVIC_INDUSTRY]Industry[\LINK]. If you're a builder, you should have no problems earning the favor of Motsqueh.

If you're a builder, you should have no problems earning the favor of Motsqueh.

TEXT.English: The Serpent Tribe was the last tribe to join the Council. They were worried that the Council would attempt to make them more docile, and in that regard they were right; but equally so, the Serpent Tribe brought a differing perspective to the table. In matters of war, the Council was often undecided, but with the Serpent Tribe at the table, it was not uncommon for them to convince the Coyote Tribe, and sometimes the Bear Tribe, into a declaration or continuation of war.

They were worried that the Council would attempt to make them more docile, and in that regard they were right; but equally so, the Serpent Tribe brought a differing perspective to the table. In matters of war, the Council was often undecided, but with the Serpent Tribe at the table, it was not uncommon for them to convince the Coyote Tribe, and sometimes the Bear Tribe, into a declaration or continuation of war.

TEXT.English: Earning the favor of the war-like Serpent Tribe grants your units [LINK=PROMOTION_COMBAT1]Combat I[\LINK]. You also receive +150% influence from pillaging, +100% [ICON_GOLD] from pillaging, and a +10% [ICON_PRODUCTION] from hurrying production through population, such as through the [LINK=CIVIC_SLAVERY]Slavery[\LINK] civic.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Serpent Tribe prefers being at war, and their favored civic is [LINK=CIVIC_CONQUEST]Conquest[\LINK]. They also earn favor by taking cities through conquest, killing units (more for orcs), pillaging, and razing orc cities. Earning their favor should be easy if you're a war-like player, but peaceful players are unlikely to earn the favor of the Serpent Tribe.

TEXT.English: The Tortoise Tribe proved more difficult to recruit than Natane and Shimasani had originally thought. True, they were isolationists, but they believed the tribe would see the wisdom in joining together. Alosaka was a rather private man, and so were his people. When approached with the proposal, he requested some time to think about it. Weeks passed, and when revisited, Alosaka still had no answer. Shimasani was unsurprised, the Tortoise Tribe wasn't known for their hasty decision making, after all. Alosaka attempted to bargain that, if he were to join, he would take no part in wars. That deal wasn't feasible, as the Council would need to come together as a unit. Ultimately, they agreed that if the Tortoise Tribe be allowed to "enlighten" the rest of the tribes through books and the practice of meditation, that they would join. Alosaka hoped his presence would be able to calm the other members of the tribe down, and he was right, up until the joining of the Serpent Tribe.

That deal wasn't feasible, as the Council would need to come together as a unit. Ultimately, they agreed that if the Tortoise Tribe be allowed to "enlighten" the rest of the tribes through books and the practice of meditation, that they would join. Alosaka hoped his presence would be able to calm the other members of the tribe down, and he was right, up until the joining of the Serpent Tribe.
TEXT.Spanish: The Tortoise Tribe proved more difficult to recruit than Natane and Shimasani had originally thought. True, they were isolationists, but they believed the tribe would see the wisdom in joining together. Alosaka was a rather private man, and so were his people. When approached with the proposal, he requested some time to think about it. Weeks passed, and when revisited, Alosaka still had no answer. Shimasani was unsurprised, the Tortoise Tribe wasn't known for their hasty decision making, after all. Alosaka attempted to bargain that, if he were to join, he would take no part in wars. That deal wasn't feasible, as the Council would need to come together as a unit. Ultimately, they agreed that if the Tortoise Tribe be allowed to "enlighten" the rest of the tribes through books and the practice of meditation, that they would join. Alosaka hoped his presence would be able to calm the other members of the tribe down, and he was right, up until the joining of the Serpent Tribe.

TEXT.English: Earning the favor of the Tortoise Tribe will grant your units [LINK=PROMOTION_CITY_GARRISON1]City Garrison I[\LINK], and you will receive +50% [ICON_GREATPEOPLE]. Additionally, your borders will not be influenced by combat, and while at peace, you will receive +15% [ICON_RESEARCH].[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Tortoise Tribe prefers being at peace, and their preferred civic is [LINK=CIVIC_SCHOLARSHIP]Scholarship[\LINK]. You can earn their favor by training units, killing units within your own borders, and by producing great people. If you prefer peace, but keep yourself well-defended to discourage attackers, you shouldn't have any problems maintaining your favor with the Tortoise Tribe.

TEXT.English: The Pioneer trait doubles the production speed for Settlers and Workers, and gives them the [LINK=PROMOTION_MOBILITY1]Mobility I[\LINK] promotion. Additionally, it gives Settler units the [LINK=PROMOTION_SETTLER_ESCORT]Settler Escort[\LINK] promotion, giving them 5 strength. This allows, especially earlier in the game, a settler to move about safer than normal. It would still be wise to have another unit accompany the Settler, but if the other unit dies, your Settler will not automatically be lost.
